mn141:2.1: This is in reference to the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta, the so-called First Sermon (SN 56.11), for which the current discourse serves as a canonical commentary.
mn141:3.1: The four noble truths are sometimes said to be like a doctor who identifies the illness, discerns its cause, understands the recovery, and administers the cure until the patient is restored to health (SA 389 at T ii 105a25; SA-2 254 at T ii 462c10). This analogy is not found in the Pali canon.
mn141:5.4: To extol his leading students, the Buddha recalls his own upbringing, born of Māyā and raised by Mahāpajāpatī (who appears in the next discourse). Nonetheless, janetā is a masculine noun and it would be misleading to translate it as “mother”. Both mother and father “give birth” (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 6.4.14; the creator is male at 1.4.4).
mn141:5.5: Āpādetā is a causative agent noun from ā + √pad in the sense “one who raises”. Again, both mother and father are “raisers” (āpādakā) of the child (AN 4.63:2.6).
mn141:11.1: Here Sāriputta takes the analysis a step further than the Dhammacakkappavattanasutta. This extended analysis of the truths was adopted from here into DN 22:18.4, which further expanded the sections on the second and third noble truths in Abhidhamma style shared with Vb 4. | The definitions of rebirth, old age, and death are standard in dependent origination (SN 12.2:4.2), and are taught by Sāriputta also at MN 9:22.2.
mn141:20.1: The five aggregates sum up the entirety of suffering, since all suffering is experienced within and by means of the aggregates.
mn141:21.1: The second and third noble truths are here analyzed to the same level of depth as the First Sermon, with no further definition of terms. See MN 9:16.2 for notes.
mn141:24.2: From here we have the standard definitions of the items of the noble eightfold path (SN 45.8:3.2; compare MN 117). | Ignorance is described in the opposite way (MN 9:64–66.7, SN 12.2:14.2).
mn141:26.1: The items of right speech and right action are covered in greater detail under the ten pathways of skilful deeds at MN 41:12.4.
